data.title: Ferdinand VII Of Spain Biography
data.meta_description: A behind-the-scene look at the life of Ferdinand VII of Spain.
data.text:
Ferdinand VII was a King of Spain who reigned twice, once in 1808 for a brief period and again from 1813 till his death. The royalists who supported him referred to him as 'el Deseado' or 'the Desired,' whereas the liberals who wanted freedom from absolute monarchy called him 'el Rey Felón' or the 'Felon King'. After Napoleon took over, he retaliated and implemented policies that divided Spain into two significant factions with his armies on one side and the dissidents on the other. After he returned to power, he established absolute monarchy with the sole authority residing on the crown. His dismissal of the constitution resulted in several uprisings and revolts spearheaded by Col. Rafael del Riego. Eventually, a Liberal Triennium was agreed upon where the liberals would rule for three years. After the Congress of Verona, France invaded Spain, which ultimately led to his restoration as a king again. Ferdinand reigned until his death and subdued any dissent showed by his opposition, banned the printing of liberal manuscripts, and ordered arrests of several dissenters. Spain was virtually bankrupt as its economy suffered significant losses due to the volatile political climate, and after his death, civil war erupted in Spain.
